intro: Vicia sallei, commonly known as the Salley vetch, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its trifoliate leaves and small, yellowish-pink flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and wastelands. Vicia sallei is a perennial herb that can reach heights of up to 60 centimeters, with slender stems and clusters of pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. It plays a role in nitrogen fixation, contributing to soil fertility in its native environments.
